content:
Protein Structure Prediction: Single Protein

What This Analysis Does

This app predicts the three-dimensional structure of proteins from their amino acid sequences using AlphaFold2, a breakthrough artificial intelligence system that achieves accuracy comparable to experimental methods. Understanding protein structure is fundamental to understanding protein function, as structure determines how proteins interact with other molecules, catalyze reactions, and perform their biological roles.

AlphaFold2 can predict structures with remarkable accuracy (often matching X-ray crystallography results), making it possible to determine structures for proteins that are difficult or impossible to crystallize.

When To Use This

  • Protein Function Discovery: Understand what your protein does by seeing its structure
  • Drug Discovery: Identify binding pockets and design small molecules to target proteins
  • Protein Engineering: Plan mutations by understanding structural context
  • Disease Research: Predict how disease-causing mutations affect protein folding
  • Structural Genomics: Annotate genomes with predicted protein structures
  • Evolutionary Studies: Compare structures across species to understand conservation

What You Need

1. Protein Sequences (FASTA Files)

You need the amino acid sequences of your proteins in FASTA format:

  • Source: Protein sequences from databases (UniProt, NCBI) or predicted from your genome
  • Format: Standard FASTA format with single-letter amino acid codes
  • Length: Works best for proteins 50-2000 amino acids (typical protein range)
  • Quality: Complete sequences work best; partial sequences may give partial predictions

Example FASTA format:

>my_protein Description of protein


2. Sample Information Sheet (CSV File)

Create a CSV file listing your proteins with this exact format:

id,fasta
protein1,protein1.fasta
protein2,protein2.fasta
protein3,protein3.fasta

Column Details:

  • id: A unique identifier for this protein (used in output file naming)
  • fasta: Path to the FASTA file containing the amino acid sequence (can be URL or stash path)

Important Notes:

  • Each FASTA file should contain ONE protein sequence (monomer prediction)
  • For protein complexes or multi-chain proteins, use a different app
  • FASTA files can be local paths or URLs (e.g., from nf-core test-datasets)

3. Output Directory

Specify where to save the predicted structures and analysis files.

What You'll Get

Predicted Structures (PDB Files)

  • Ranked models: 5 different structure predictions ranked by confidence
  • Relaxed structures: Energy-minimized structures for downstream use
  • Best model: Top-ranked prediction (usually rank_001)
  • Ensemble: Multiple predictions showing structural variability

Confidence Scores

  • pLDDT scores: Per-residue confidence (0-100, higher is better)
  • Color-coded PDB: Structures colored by confidence (blue=high, red=low)
  • PAE plots: Predicted Aligned Error showing which regions are well-predicted relative to each other
  • Overall confidence: Global quality assessment

Analysis Files

  • Feature files: Multiple sequence alignment and evolutionary information
  • Timings: Runtime statistics for each prediction step
  • Logs: Detailed processing information
  • Summary report: MultiQC report with all predictions

Interpreting Confidence Scores

pLDDT (predicted Local Distance Difference Test):

  • >90: Very high confidence - structure is very reliable
  • 70-90: High confidence - structure is generally reliable
  • 50-70: Low confidence - structure may have errors
  • <50: Very low confidence - often disordered regions or poor predictions

Typical patterns:

  • Structured domains usually score 70-100
  • Loops and flexible regions score 50-70
  • Disordered regions score below 50 (these are naturally unstructured)

Expected Analysis Time

  • Small protein (50-150 residues): 10-20 minutes on XSMALL with GPU
  • Typical protein (150-400 residues): 20-40 minutes on SMALL with GPU
  • Large protein (400-800 residues): 40-90 minutes on MEDIUM with GPU
  • Very large protein (800-2000 residues): 1.5-3 hours on LARGE with GPU

Note: GPU dramatically speeds up predictions (10-100x faster than CPU). Times are estimates for GPU execution.

Scientific Background

AlphaFold2, developed by DeepMind, represents a major breakthrough in computational biology. It uses deep learning trained on known protein structures and evolutionary information to predict how proteins fold. The model achieved unprecedented accuracy in the CASP14 competition (2020), often matching experimental methods.

The algorithm works by:

  1. Searching databases for evolutionarily related sequences
  2. Building multiple sequence alignments to capture evolutionary constraints
  3. Using neural networks to predict inter-residue distances and angles
  4. Optimizing the structure to satisfy these geometric constraints
  5. Refining the structure through energy minimization

The monomer_ptm model preset used here also predicts pTM (predicted TM-score), which assesses overall structural confidence.

Tips for Success

  • Complete sequences: Full-length sequences give best results
  • Single domains: Well-defined domains predict better than full-length proteins with disordered regions
  • Check confidence: Always examine pLDDT scores; low scores indicate uncertain predictions
  • Multiple models: Compare the 5 ranked models to assess prediction stability
  • Validation: If possible, compare to known structures of homologs

Limitations

  • No small molecules: Predictions don't include cofactors, metals, or ligands
  • Single conformations: Predicts one structure, but proteins may have multiple functional states
  • Membrane proteins: More challenging, especially transmembrane regions
  • Intrinsically disordered: Cannot predict structure for naturally disordered proteins
  • Novel folds: Works best for proteins similar to training data

Advanced users: See full pipeline documentation

Read the AlphaFold2 paper in Nature
command: nextflow run nf-core/proteinfold --input ${input} --outdir ${output} --mode alphafold2 --alphafold2_model_preset monomer_ptm --use_gpu false --full_dbs false --num_recycle 3 -r 1.1.1 -c /etc/mpi/nextflow.camber.config -profile singularity
